body: COLLINS-Margaretta P. (nee Egan), native of County Roscommon, Ireland. Devoted wife of the late Michael F. Beloved mother of Michael, Mary Teresa Macchiarola, Martin and Rev. James P. (Chaplain of Bishop Kearney H.S.). Loving mother-in-law of Patricia and Frank. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Joseph, Michael and Frank Macchiarola. Funeral
title: Paid Notice: Deaths COLLINS, MARGARETTA P. (NEE EGAN)

body: Pudgie Walsh, gruff former firefighter and longtime coach of the Brooklyn Mariners, was hardly surprised when television producers turned up recently and asked to base a series on his life. After all, for the 44 seasons that Mr. Walsh has coached the Mariners, a semipro football team from Sheepshead Bay, people have always called him a character.
title: A Larger-Than-Life Coach, Embellished for the Small Screen

body: The mugwort sounds like a villain from a Harry Potter novel, or the name of some plug-ugly in a bad 1930's prison movie. It's not a pretty plant, nor, by plant standards, is it very nice. To reproduce, it's quite capable of giving less aggressive flora an elbow in the eye and a shove toward extinction. The mugwort's a survivor. The persimmon, on
title: Return of the Natives: Playing God in the Fields; Planting the Past Anew in New York City

body: INTERNATIONAL 3-18 At Least 170 Skiers Die In Austria Tunnel Fire At least 170 people were killed above the Alpine village of Kaprun near Salzburg as the cable car they were taking to a glacier ski run stalled inside a mountain tunnel and burst into flames, the provincial governor said. Rescue workers said many bodies were so badly charred that it
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: It was a place of the discarded and the dead. There were no roads. There was said to be nothing green that could live. The smell could sicken at a distance of two miles. In the early years of the 20th century, the tiny island off the coast of Brooklyn was a nightmare: a dumping ground for most of the trash and animal carcasses of the teeming city.
title: All the Dead Horses, Next Door; Bittersweet Memories of the City's Island of Garbage

body: THE view is terrific, even if it's from the top of a massive trash heap. The wide swath of the Hudson River and the breathtaking skyline of Manhattan are to the east, and the rolling hills of northern New Jersey march north and west. If current plans are carried out, this moonscape of construction debris and industrial waste rising from the watery
title: Commercial Property; Turning Brownfields Into Fairways and Greens

body: NEW YORKERS are often accused of being addicted to the adrenaline rush. If that is true, here are four recent mystery novels with New York locales that might rev up the heartbeats of readers hereabouts. THE WRONG DOG: A Rachel Alexander and Dash Mystery By Carol Lea Benjamin Walker & Company ($23.95, hardcover) It was an old building, like the back
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF; Crime May Be Down, But Not in Novels

body: On two days in June, groups of teenage boys sexually assaulted girls in two New York City schoolyards during school hours, but the safety officers and administrators on duty failed to take action or notify the police, according to a report issued yesterday by the special investigator for the city school system. The second of those assaults went
title: Report Faults Schools' Inaction in Attacks

author: Mindy Aloff is the dance critic for The New Republic.
body: Until the current craze for golf brought the game into high visibility, everything I knew about golf technique I learned from a dancer: Fred Astaire. Astaire was a passionate off-screen golfer and in ''Carefree,'' his 1938 movie with Ginger Rogers, he included a golf solo for himself, to a tune by Irving Berlin. The choreography is built around two
title: With Fred Astaire to Emulate, Can Golf Be That Hard?

body: A year ago, the Gerritsen Creek salt marshes on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn were simply ''the creek,'' a fishing spot and informal local dump. They were a place to toss old tires and rusting car hulks, or for teenagers to hide out for clandestine beer parties. Old-timers could do a bit of illegal muskrat hunting or crab netting there. Now, like a worn
title: Come On In, the Swamp Is Fine; Wetland Beauty Restored, Just Off Flatbush Avenue

body: NEWS Honor Bound Ushering in a new annual accolade, the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music will present its first Brooklyn Conservatory of Music Award to the jazz pianist, composer and educator Billy Taylor. The unrestricted cash prize of $25,000 will be presented on Sept. 18 at a benefit for student scholarships at the Supper Club in Manhattan. The
title: FOOTLIGHTS

body: Last September, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority temporarily closed the walkway across the Marine Parkway-Gil Hodges Memorial Bridge. The agency is widening the roadway across the bridge, and the walkway will be closed until spring 2001. The closing poses no problem for in-line skaters and pedestrians, who can jump on the Q35 bus, which
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE; The Bike-to-the-Bus Falters, And the M.T.A. Tries a Fix

Dorismond, the unarmed son of Haitian immigrants who was shot to death in a confrontation with the police on March 16, was carried across Brooklyn, eulogized as a martyr and laid to rest yesterday after a march and funeral that drew thousands of anguished mourners and
title: Angry Mourners and Police Clash At Funeral of Man Shot by Officer

body: By the end of the afternoon, the crowds had cleared and no one was dead. But the angry outbursts of violence that erupted in Brooklyn yesterday before and after the funeral of Patrick M. Dorismond were perhaps the most severe clashes between civilians and the police since the Tompkins Square Park disturbances in 1989. The violent protests, in which
title: Police Say Officers' Calm Averted Worse Violence

body: More than a thousand mourners filled a funeral home in Brooklyn and the streets outside last night to pay respects to Patrick Dorismond, the 26-year-old security guard killed by a plainclothes police officer last week. Dozens carried or wore the Haitian flag, and Mr. Dorismond's cousins, who are renowned Haitian musicians, sang for him. Across
title: Police Shooting Victim Is Remembered and Mourned in Tears and Song

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Capturing Time: The New York Times Capsule'' includes some of the nearly 50 design proposals received in a New York Times Magazine competition. The winning capsule design, by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava, has its own special display.
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Past-Prime Pretzels Q. Sometimes the soft pretzels I buy on the street are not so soft. How long are they allowed to sit around before they are considered stale? A. body: A young man speeding in a Mercedes-Benz on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn struck a Honda from behind early yesterday, causing it to roll over and slam into a limousine parked at a roadside gas station, the police said. Two passengers in the Honda died, and a third was in critical condition last night. Eight other people suffered minor injuries. The
title: Driver Charged With Murder in 3-Car Crash That Killed 2

body: New York City's emergency rooms, nursing homes and employers are facing down an odious flu that came late and with a vengeance, bringing with it a cousin -- a cough and ache-producing, endlessly protracted bug that is not really flu at all but is perhaps even more miserable. From lower Manhattan to the farthest reaches of Queens, hospitals are
title: Flu Cases Jam the E.R. and Empty the Office
